caseProcess.description: An investigation was initiated by the Norwood, Unionville Procuratorate following a series of complaints from brand owners regarding counterfeit goods being sold at a retail shop owned by the defendant, C. Taylor.
Detention measures were authorized by the court against C. Taylor after substantial evidence was collected implicating her in the sale of counterfeit branded goods.
C. Taylor was formally placed under criminal detention as per the arrest warrant issued by the Norwood, Unionville Court.
An arrest order was executed by the Norwood police, officially arresting C. Taylor for the crime of selling counterfeit registered trademark goods.

criminalFacts.crimeName: Crime of Selling Counterfeit Registered Trademark Goods

details.behavior: C. Taylor knowingly sold counterfeit branded handbags under the trademarks of renowned brands such as Louis Vuitton, Chanel, and Gucci at her retail shop located at 25 Baker Street, Unionville.
details.evidence: Physical evidence consisting of over 200 counterfeit handbags found during a police raid, financial records indicating transactions worth $45,000 linked to the sale of these counterfeit goods, and testimony from multiple witnesses who confirmed purchasing said counterfeit items.

details.behavior: C. Taylor acquired a shipment of counterfeit Nike shoes from an unverified supplier and displayed them for sale in her shop.
details.evidence: Invoices and delivery receipts reflecting the acquisition of 150 pairs of shoes for $12,000, as well as physical evidence of the counterfeit shoes seized from her shop.

details.behavior: C. Taylor promoted a special sale event on social media advertising discounted prices on various luxury brands' goods, which were later discovered to be counterfeit.
details.evidence: Screenshots from social media platforms of promotional posts, testimonies from customers who purchased these counterfeit items, and the financial trail reflecting a total of $20,000 in sales during the promotional event.

details.behavior: C. Taylor attempted to cover up her crimes by disposing of counterfeit goods at a nearby dumping ground following rumors of investigation.
details.evidence: Witness statements from local residents who saw C. Taylor disposing multiple branded bags, and forensic reports matching the discarded items to her inventory.

judgmentResult.crimeName: Crime of Selling Counterfeit Registered Trademark Goods
judgmentResult.sentence: C. Taylor was sentenced to four years of fixed-term imprisonment and fined $100,000 for illicit gains.
judgmentResult.sentencingConsiderations: The sentencing considered the large scale of the counterfeit goods sold, significant monetary gains, and attempts to obstruct justice by disposing of evidence.
